III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
Section (1) An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
Description parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(a) A plan of visitation for each child in foster care consistent
with the child’s service plans, as required by R 400.12419 and R
400.12420 to assure the safety and well-being of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Respondent mother has not been offered parenting time with two
of her children who are in care for approximately 5 weeks.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Chief Administrator was interviewed via Teams on 5/2/2023.
She reported Parent A has always been offered parenting time,
but she has not always participated due to lack of confirming visits
or refusing to visit at the agency.
Parent A/Complainant was interviewed by phone on 4/28/2023.
She reported she hasn’t had a visit with her children, Youth A &
Youth B, for 5 weeks. She stated visits were previously occurring
at her home until a safety plan was put into place for Youth B,
requiring a change in location. Parent A stated Foster Care
Worker has not given her a reason why Youth B’s visits can’t
occur at her home. Parent A has two other children in foster care
through a different private agency and those children continue to
have twice per week visits in Parent A’s home. Parent A stated
there are reasons why Youth B’s visits can’t always occur, such as
his current hospitalization, so Youth A’s visits are the visits she’s
concerned about. She stated Foster Care Worker has offered her
visits at the agency, but Parent A’s car isn’t working, so she
cannot get to the office. She stated Foster Care Worker did offer
her bus passes, but there is no bus that transports from her home
location to the office. Parent A added Foster Care Worker offers
her visits during times when Parent A works.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via Teams on 5/2/2023.
She reported that a separate private agency has full family
responsibility for Parent A’s case and also has case management
responsibility of two of Parent A’s children. Foster Care Supervisor
is responsible for supervising the cases of Youth A & Youth B.
Prior to March of 2023, the two agencies were coordinating visits
with all children. In March, the other agency moved the visits to
the home of Parent A. Youth A & Youth B’s visits were also moved
to Parent A’s home at that time. Two visits occurred in Parent A’s
home before it was decided that Youth A and Youth B could no
2

longer visit in the home due to concerns with Youth B’s behavior.
Additionally, there is a pending trial for termination of Parent A’s
rights, so the agency staff determined it could be traumatizing to
the youth to have visitation in Parent A’s home. Foster Care
Supervisor reported it was verbally ordered at court yesterday,
5/1/2023, that visits were to be supervised at the agency office.
Director was interviewed via Teams on 5/2/2023. She reported
visits in Parent A’s home have been determined to be a safety risk
based on the pending termination hearing and the potential for
Parent A to present a safety risk to the agency staff or children.
Director reported the visits that did take place in Parent A’s home
did not go well due to Youth B being a flight risk and having a
history of elopement. Director reported it was determined by
agency staff it would be best to hold the visits in a controlled
environment, so the visits between Parent A, Youth A, and Youth
B were moved to the agency office. Director stated Parent A
hasn’t seen the youths in 4 weeks because she has either failed to
confirm her scheduled visits or refuses to visit at the office.
Director reported Parent A has not been denied visits and is
always offered visits on Thursday at the agency office with Youth
A. Youth B has been hospitalized for mental health concerns since
4/20/2023 and Parent A can and has participated in visits with him
at the hospital. Director stated Parent A has had a car and has
been able to get rides from family members when needed.
Director reported Parent A’s work schedule has changes several
times throughout the case and agency staff have worked with her
to change the times of visits to accommodate her schedule.
Director reported Parent A has not had an in person visit with
Youth A since 3/23/2023 due to Parent A failing to confirm her
visits or wanting visits to occur at her home; however, she had a
video with Youth A on her birthday 4/8/2023, which was a
Saturday, at Parent A’s request. Parent A visited Youth B in the
hospital, where Youth B is currently placed on 4/23/2023 and
4/28/2023. Parent A also had a brief visit with Youth A via video
following Youth A’s psychological evaluation. Director reported
parenting time is scheduled this coming Thursday with Youth A.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed vis Teams on 5/2/2023. She
reported Parent A did have a working car and has utilized family
members for rides to her visits, when needed. Foster Care Worker
did offer Parent A bus passes in order for her to get to the visits,
but Parent A refused them without explanation. Foster Care
Worker stated she believed there was a bus route from Parent A’s
home to the office and Parent A has not told her there is not;
3

however, she will look into the route. Foster Care Worker reported
the visits are scheduled to accommodate the youths’ school
schedule as well as Parent A’s work schedule and Parent A
contacted her this week to let her know her work schedule had
changed after which the visit times were changed. Foster Care
Worker reported the court has now ordered visits to be supervised
at the agency office.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
Case Contacts in MiSACWIS:
• 3/17/2023 – Visit with Youth A & Youth B at Parent A’s
home. Youth B refused to leave Parent A’s home, then
refused to go into his foster parent’s home, threatening to
run away
• 3/23/2023 – Visit with Youth A & Youth B at community
restaurant. Parent A informed visits could no longer occur
in her home.
• 3/30/2023 – No visit due to Parent A not contacting Foster
Care Worker
• 4/3/2023 – FTM during which a decision to no longer allow
visits at Parent A’s home was made
• 4/6/2023 - No visit due to Parent A wanting the visit at her
home
• 4/8/2023 – Video visit with Youth A for her birthday
• 4/13/2023 -No visit due to Parent A wanting the visit at her
home
• 4/14/2023 – Visit cancelled due to Parent A’s failure to
confirm
• 4/20/23 – Video visit with Youth B following a psychological
evaluation
• 4/23/2023 – Visit with Youth B at the hospital
• 4/27/2023 – No visit with Youth A due to Parent A failing to
confirm
• 4/28/2023 – Visit with Youth B at the hospital
Family Team Meeting documents in MiSACWIS:
• 4/3/2023, Parent A present, decision to continue Youth A
and Youth B’s visits at the agency office pending a clinical
evaluation to determine appropriateness of visitation at
Parent A’s home by 5/25/2023.
Emails:
• 5/2/2023 from Director indicating agency staff have
confirmed there is a bus route from Parent A’s home to the
4

agency and that route will be provided to Parent A should
need it for future visits.
• 5/2/2023 from Director indicating Youth B will begin
therapeutic services upon discharge from the hospital as
which time a clinical evaluation regarding visitation will be
requested.
Visitation Plan in MiSACWIS:
• Supervised, 2 hours weekly with Parent A at a relative’s
home.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as Parent A is offered
parenting time weekly at the agency.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Best practice is to update visitation plans whenever a change to
the frequency, duration, or location is made. These plans should
be updated between service plans, if needed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
Section (1) An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
Description parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(d) Provisions for visits between siblings who are not placed
together except when there is a court determination that visits are
detrimental to either child.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The youths are not being provided sibling visitation.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Parent A/Complainant was interviewed by phone on 4/28/2023.
She reported Youth A and Youth B have not had visits with their
siblings who are also in foster care for approximately five weeks.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via Teams on 5/2/2023.
Foster Care Worker reported no sibling visits occurred in April.
She stated sibling visits were occurring during parenting times, but
since the visit locations were changed for the youths, they have
not occurred. She stated the worker for Youth A & Youth B’s
siblings stated the sibling visits would continue to occur in Parent
A’s home, despite Foster Care Worker no longer permitting
visitation for Youth A & Youth B in Parent A’s home. Foster Care
Worker has been attempting coordinate a sibling visit at a different
location; however, the siblings’ worker continues to want the
sibling visits to occur in Parent A’s home.
5

Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via Teams on 5/2/2023.
Foster Care Supervisor stated the change in visitation location as
well as sibling visits were discussed during a 4/3/2023 Family
Team Meeting. During that meeting, the worker for Youth A &
Youth B’s siblings wanted the sibling visits to continue at Parent
A’s home. Foster Care Supervisor reported reaching out to the
other agency multiple time, including yesterday, to try to
coordinate sibling visits at a different location. She reported she
will continue to work with that agency to ensure sibling visits
occur.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
Case Contacts in MiSACWIS:
• 3/9/2023 Sibling Visit at Parent A’s home is last sibling visit
documented.
Family Team Meeting documents in MiSACWIS:
• 4/3/2023 worker for Youth A & Youth B’s siblings stated
visits with those siblings would continue to occur in Parent
A’s home and sibling visits could occur there.
Visitation Plan in MiSACWIS:
• Supervised, 2 hours weekly with Parent A at a relative’s
home.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as they do have provisions for
sibling visits and are making attempts to resolve the location
issues that have prevented the sibling visits.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: The report details an investigation into allegations that a parent was denied parenting time and that sibling visits were not occurring for two children in foster care. The investigation found that the agency consistently offered weekly visits at its office, but the parent often failed to confirm or refused to attend because she preferred visits at her home. A safety concern and a court order dictated the change in location from the parent's home to the agency. Sibling visits were hindered because the other agency involved insisted they occur at the parent's home, which was now deemed inappropriate. The agency was found in compliance with all rules; the evidence suggests the parent's own actions and a coordination issue with another agency were primary causes for the lack of in-person visits.
